properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Chandlers Creek, Weeragua. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice - Stay Informed issued at 1 pm, Sunday January 12.
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area:
  • Emergency services will continue to monitor the situation. 
  • Smoke may be visible from this and other bushfires in the landscape from nearby communities and roads.   
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Avenel, Dairy Creek, Granite, Homewood, Kerrisdale, Strath Creek, Trawool, Whiteheads Creek.
  • This Advice replaces the advice message issued at 7pm 13/1
  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • Roads are being prioritised and assessed for safe access.
Community newsletter here: 

Community Newsletter 13-1-2026
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.

Traffic Management points are currently in place for this fire. We're asking those who are not local to the area to avoid unnecessary travel to respect that only people who need to get through will be given access. Traffic management points are in place to ensure your safety and you may be asked for ID. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2026 01:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to the Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire in the Tallangatta Valley. 
  • The bushfire is out of control.
  • Favorable weather conditions are providing an opportunity for our crews to conduct controlled back burning and you may see smoke in the area over the next few days.
  • There is a relief centre at Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre. 
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services.  
  • This Watch and Act warning replaces the Watch and Act issued at 9.14 pm.
If you left the warning area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre, which allows pets. 
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • For NSW RFS information click here or go to www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/major-fire-updates
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 09:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South.
  • The fire in the Natimuk, Quantong and Vectis area is now contained. 
  • Firefighters, emergency services and Powercor continue to work on the fire, treatment of fire affected trees and repair of powerlines. 
  • Residents should stay alert for dangerous trees and electrical hazards. 
  • The Wimmera Highway is open for all traffic through Natimuk. 
  • All roads east of the Wimmera River in the Quantong and Vectis area are open.
  • Some local roads remain closed due to safety concerns. Continue to obey all road signage. 
  • A recovery centre is open from 10am to 4pm daily at 62 Main Street, Natimuk.
  • For recovery information visit the HRCC Grass Flat Fire Recovery web page. 
This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 12:52pm Mondah 12th January 2026.

While the threat is reduced, there is still active fire in the area. The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation, noting there is still active fire in the area. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.  
  • Watch out for essential services and vehicles working in the area.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • There are still powerlines down and hazardous trees within the fire ground.
  • Access to Natimuk township is via the Wimmera Highway only.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.   

The next update is expected by 14/01/2026 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Kialla, Mooroopna, Toolamba .

  • There is a haystack fire at Pogue Rd, Toolamba. 
  • Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities.
  • Firefighters are attending to this fire. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Smoke information:
  • Smoke can affect peoples health. For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/health/videos/Smoke-and-your-health-protect-your-health.  
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Abbeyard, Arbuckle, Billabong, Black Snake Creek, Budgee Budgee, Castleburn, Cobbannah, Cowa, Crooked River, Dargo, Gibbs, Grant, Hawkhurst, Hogtown, Howitt Plains, Howittville, Maguires, Miowera, Moornapa, Moroka, Naarun, Peter the Swede, Selwyn, Shepherdson, Talbotville, Toolome, Treasure, Waterford, Winchester, Wongungarra, Wonnangatta, Wrathung.
  • There is a bushfire at Mt Darling - Cynthia Range (Dargo - Wonnangatta Complex) that is not yet under control.
  • Fire activity remains.  Monitor conditions and be ready to act. 
  • Emergency Services, Machinery and Aircraft are operating in the area and are working on supressing the fire edges and building control lines. 
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 1pm Monday 12th January.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
 What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Have a bushfire plan. Visit the CFA website for details on how to prepare your and your property for a bushfire.   Visit https://www.cfa.vic.gov.au
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:

The following roads are restricted to residents and property owners only. Access will be permitted for essential maintenance and animal care. Proof of ownership is required and must be provided via Drivers Licence or Rates Notice. 
  • Bairnsdale-Dargo Road at the Beverleys Road Junction 
  • Freestone Creek Road at Coopers Road   

The following roads are closed: 
  • Dargo High Plain Road between Dargo and Great Alpine Road 
  • Marathon Road at the Moroka Road Junction 
  • Marathon Road at the Boundary 24 Track Junction   
  • Wallers Road (between Friday Creek Road and Bairnsdale-Dargo Road)
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

The following Parks/Areas are closed to the public:  
  • Blue Pool on Freestone Creek Road is Closed   
  • The Alpine National Park north of Briagolong, East of Arbuckle Junction and Mount Howitt, west of Dargo including the Wonnangatta, and south of Abbeyard, west of the Great Alpine Rd to Lake Cobbler is Closed.  
  • The Mitchell River National Park is Closed 

Emergency Services are operating in the area.  
Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/alpine-national-park#change-of-conditions
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Karbethong, Lake View, Mallacoota, Wingan River
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Karbethong, Lake View, Mallacoota, Wingan River.
  • There are bushfires at Mallacoota - Lake Barracoota and Cape Howe that are not yet under control.
  • The Mallacoota - Lake Barracoota bushfire continues to grow and is approximately 2000 hectares.
  • Generally southerly winds are expected to increase in strength today, pushing the fire northwards.
  • 7 aircraft including 3 from NSW are working together on suppressing the Lake Barracoota fire.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions, which may change.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke is visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions.

  • There is a bushfire at 25Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire has travelled south from the Mt Lawson State Park, has crossed the Murray Valley Highway, and continues to travel south towards Mitta Mitta and Dartmouth.

properties.location: Creighton, Creightons Creek, Euroa, Kithbrook, Longwood, Pranjip, Sheans Creek
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Creighton, Creightons Creek, Euroa, Kithbrook, Longwood, Pranjip, Sheans Creek.

  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • Roads in this area may be too dangerous to travel due to fire-damaged trees and tree-limbs, and other hazards like damaged power poles. 
  • Fire and works crews are patrolling these areas for fire, and working to clear safe road access.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 8.39pm on Monday 12th January. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.

Roads in this area maybe too dangerous to travel. Traffic Management Points are in place for your safety.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan.
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Relief Centres are open at:
  • Benalla Relief Centre, Town Hall 82-86 Nunn Street, Benalla
Impacts in your area:
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.  
  • Check the VicTraffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Traffic management is in place for this fire: 
  • We're asking those who are not local to the area to avoid unnecessary travel to respect that only people who need to get through will be given access. 
  • You may be asked for ID.
  • Traffic management is to ensure your safety. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 07:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh, Koetong, Shelley, Berringama, Lucyvale and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh, Koetong, Shelley, Berringama, Lucyvale and surrounds. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh, Koetong, Shelley, Berringama, Lucyvale and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire at 25km West of Walwa that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire is still active in this area and crews are working to strengthen containment lines and conduct controlled back burning.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services. 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 11:11pm on the 12/01/26.
If you left the area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre Cnr Wilson and Mitchell Street Wodonga.
  • Register at the relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions. 
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you.  
Road closures
  • Murray River Road from Granya Road, Granya to Main Street, Walwa. 
  • The Murray Valley Highway is closed from Cudgewa Valley Road to Old Tallangatta.
  • Shelley Road from Guys Forest Road to Murray Valley Highway. 
  • Travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossings at Jinjellic Rd, Tintaldra, Towong and Towong Upper. 
  • Keep up to date with road closures by monitoring the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70. 

For NSW RFS information click here or go to www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/major-fire-updates
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 07:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Georges Creek, Jarvis Creek, Bethanga, Old Tallangatta, Noorongong, Tallangatta and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters have not been able to stop the fire. The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • You will be able to utilise the bridge at Old Tallangatta, but you should consider your alternate routes. 
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre - Crn Wilson and Mitchell Street Wodonga.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued 9:53PM issued on the 12/01/26.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Have more than one way to get emergency Information. Mobile phone networks, internet service and electricity supply may be disrupted or unavailable. Have back-up ways to receive warnings such as listening to the radio, checking community notice points or following instructions from emergency services on the ground.
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to the relief centres above. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • For NSW RFS information click here or go to www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/major-fire-updates
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Road closures:
  • The Murray Valley Highway is closed at the Lake Road intersection. 
  • Granya Road from Murray River Road to Rhodes Street Granya.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 10:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Harcourt.
  • As of 11:45am Saturday 10 January, the tap water at Harcourt is not safe to drink. 
  • The Harcourt supply system also supplies areas south of Harcourt.
  • This advice has been issued following the impact of the fires in Harcourt on Friday 9 January 2026. Water services have been unable to safely access a burst water main, which may have caused contaminants to enter the water supply network.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 7.22pm on 11th January.
Tap water is not safe to drink in Harcourt. Boiling the tap water will not make it safe. 
What you should do: 
  • Do not drink tap water.
  • You should only drink bottled water. 
  • If you are unsure if the water is safe to drink, you should not drink it.
  • For more information, visit: https://coliban.com.au/interruptions/do-not-drink-advisory-harcourt
It is unsafe to use tap water for: 
  • Food preparation, cleaning food or preparing baby formula. 
  • Cleaning dishes.
  • Making ice, brushing teeth and preparing beverages.
Maintaining personal hygiene: 
  • It is important to stay clean. 
  • Use hand sanitiser after going to the bathroom and before you consume food. 
  • Use disposable baby wipe products that are not soap based without water to clean yourself. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • All residents are asked to not drink tap water until further notice.
  • A drinking water trailer for impacted residents is available at Rodilesa Nursery, on the corner of Blackjack Road and Midland Highway in Harcourt. Please only take what you need.
This message was issued by Department of Health.  

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed:  
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.    
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Longwood, Longwood East. 
  • As of Saturday 10 January 2026, people in Longwood and Longwood East should boil their tap water before consumption. 
  • The Longwood fire has impacted the operations of the Longwood Water Treatment Plant and this has impacted water supply to customers. 
  • Water is being brought into local storage tanks, which is now supplying the town.
  • This Advice message replaces the Community Information issued at 9:40 pm Saturday, 10 January 2026.
If you live or work within Longwood or Longwood East, you must boil tap water before drinking. 
What you should do:  
  • Boil water before drinking it, or drink bottled water.
  • Boil water for food preparation, cleaning fruit and vegetables, making ice and for preparing baby formula.
  • Boil water for brushing teeth. 
To ensure water is safe, you should: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable). 
  • Allow water to cool before use. 
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use. 
  • Be careful when boiling water to prevent scalding or burns.
  • If you are concerned that you may have been affected by contaminated water, contact your doctor or Nurse-on-Call. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • A tanker of treated water that is safe to drink can be accessed between 8am and 4pm daily. Bring containers to fill from the tanker.
  • Bottled water is available 24 hours a day at the Longwood Recreation Reserve.
  • For more information, visit: www.gvwater.vic.gov.au  
This message was issued by Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • Fire Crews are currently working in and patrolling this area.
  • Roads are being prioritised and assessed for safe access.
ESCORTED CONVOYS-Emergency services will be facilitating strictly controlled , escorted access for specific priority needs only. This is NOT open to the general public for routine travel.  
Access is restricted to- Emergency Stock Feed & Water Transports, Emergency Services Personnel and vehicles, Essential workers (healthcare workers, utility repairs, critical infrastructure etc, and Personal critical needs such as urgent medical supplies).
Departure point-
All convoys will depart from the Traffic Management point on the Goulburn Valley Hwy, Yea.
Escort Schedule (departure time)
Please arrive 15 mins prior, escorts will depart from the assembly point at the following times only: 
  • 8.30am
  • 12.30pm
  • 3.30pm 

  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch & Act issued on Monday, 12 January 2026 at 8.40pm.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.

Traffic Management points are currently in place for this fire. 
We're asking those who are not local to the area to avoid unnecessary travel to respect that only people who need to get through will be given access. Traffic management points are in place to ensure your safety and you may be asked for ID.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 02:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barkers Creek, Harcourt, Harcourt North, Ravenswood South, Sutton Grange, Walmer. 
  • There is a grassfire that started at Fogartys Gap Road, Ravenswood South that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire crossed Calder Highway, impacted Harcourt, Mount Alexander and areas to the east towards Sutton Grange.
  • The spread of fire has slowed and is not travelling outside the current burn area, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Many trees have been impacted by fire and are considered dangerous until assessment processes are complete, these assessments are still in progress.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and may be present for the next few days. 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act issued at 6:16pm.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
Other Information:
  • A Recovery Hub opened yesterday at the Castlemaine Town Hall, 25 Lyttleton Street, on Monday, 12 January 2026. Opening hours will be from 11:00am and 5:00pm this week. 
  • For affected residents, the Recovery Hub includes a number of agencies and organisations that can assist you through the recovery process including temporary accommodation support. 
  • The replay of yesterdays community meeting can be accessed from the VicEmergency - Loddon Mallee Facebook page. 
  • The Community Newsletter for the 12 January 2026 is available here.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe.

Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Forest Fire Management have commenced burning out operations today within the Mount Alexander Regional Park, this will create additional smoke which may be visible to nearby communities. Large aircraft will be used to assist these operations.
The following roads are closed:
  • Fogartys Gap Road, Ravenswood South - from Mt Gaspard Road to Calder Freeway 
  • North Harcourt Road, Harcourt North - from Sedgwick-Sutton Grange Road to Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road 
  • Sutton Grange Road, Sedgwick - from Axe Creek Road to Grays Road 
  •  Grays Road, Sutton Grange - from Sutton Grange Road to Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road 
  • Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road, Sutton Grange - from Grays Road to Bendigo-Sutton Grange Road 
  • Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road, Sutton Grange - from Grays Road to North Harcourt Road 
  • Elphinstone-Sutton Grange Road, Elphinstone - from Finnings Road to Pollards Road 
  • Bendigo-Sutton Grange Road, Elphinstone - from Pollards Road to Grays Road, Sutton Grange 
  • Pollards Road, Elphinstone - From Calder Freeway to Harmony Way
  • Victoria Road, Harcourt - from Calder In-Ramp of, Victoria Road, Barkers Creek to Coolstore Road, Harcourt 
  • Harmony Way/Pyrenees Highway Intersection, Elphinstone  
  • McIvor Road, Harcourt North - from Harcourt-Sutton Grange Road to Reservoir Road.
  • Joseph Young Drive
  • Faraday-Sutton Grange Road from Bendigo-Sutton Grange Road to Harmony Way.
We are working on making roads safe before they open.
Check the VicTraffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 

The fire has impacted communication towers on Mount Alexander which has impacted radio broadcasting. Temporary measures are in place. Free to air TV remains offline.  
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.  

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Hotline on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Nariel Valley, Cudgewa, Corryong, Towong, Thowgla Valley, Biggara, Walwa, Burrowye and surrounds.  
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Nariel Valley, Cudgewa, Corryong, Towong, Thowgla Valley, Biggara, Walwa, Burrowye and surrounds. . 
  • There is a bushfire at 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control. 
  • Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • A relief centre is available at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre Cnr Wilson and Mitchell Street Wodonga.
  • Works are occurring to restore essential services. 
  • This replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 7:00pm yesterday.
If you left the warning area, it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Wodonga Racing and Exhibition Centre.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:

PLANNED BURNING IN THIS AREA:
  • Favorable weather conditions provided an opportunity for our crews to conduct controlled back burning. The burn along Chicks Track near Burrowye is complete but you may still see smoke in the area.

Road Closures:
  • Murray River Road from Granya Road, Granya to Main Street, Walwa.
  • The Murray Valley Highway is closed from Cudgewa Valley Road to Old Tallangatta.
  • Shelley Road from Guys Forest Road to Murray Valley Highway.
  • Travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossings at Jinjellic Rd, Tintaldra, Towong and Towong Upper.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

For information on fires in NSW click here or go to www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/major-fire-updates

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carranballac, Stoneleigh and the rural area of Skipton. 

There will be 4km of burning out along the Mailman Track south of Skipton. You may see smoke in the area. 
  • This grassfire is now contained.
  • However, it is Not Safe to Return to Carranballac, Stoneleigh and the rural area of Skipton. 
  • Hazardous trees and fallen powerlines, pose a significant risk to residents attempting to return home. 
  • Facilitating safe property access to residents in the fire affected area is a high priority and significant efforts are being focused to ensure this is done as soon as possible.
  • A hazardous tree assessment team continue work to re-open roads.
  • Powercor are on scene assessing and repairing critical infrastructure with significant progress made. Crews will now commence connections to properties.
If you left Carranballac, Streatham and the rural area of Skipton, it is Not Safe to Return.

Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A recovery hub is open at the Skipton Mechanics Hall, 5 Anderson Street, Skipton from 10am to 4pm.  Please note that the Beaufort Recovery centre is now closed. Pyrenees Shire representatives will be in attendance at the Skipton Recovery Hub.
Community Meetings:
Community meetings will be held on Tuesday, 13 January 2026 at the below locations:
  • 12pm at Beaufort Community Bank Complex (39 Park Rd, Beaufort)
  • 2pm at Streatham Memorial Hall (30 Campbell Street, Streatham)
  • 4pm at Skipton Mechanics Hall (5 Anderson Street, Skipton)
  • For further information , please read the attached Community Newsletter here: Yalla-Y-Poora Rd Streatham Fire Community Newsletter
Powercor Mobile Emergency Response Vehicle:
  • Representatives will be at Skipton Mechanics Hall on Monday, 12 January 2026 from 10am with the Mobile Emergency Response Vehicle. 
  • This is an opportunity for the community to talk to Powercor about power supply and it has capacity to charge up to 20 mobile devices.  

Road closures have changed:
  • The Glenelg Highway is closed between: Eurambeen-Streatham Road, Streatham and Skipton-Geelong Rd, Skipton. Access to residents only via Skipton-Geelong Rd Traffic Management point.
  • Eurambeen-Streatham Road at Richies Road
  • Intersection of Mt William Road and Beaufort-Carranballac Road to Carngham-Streatham Rd.
  • Lismore-Skipton Road at Leydens Lane
  • Vite-Vite Skipton Road at Walkers Road
  • 4km South of Darlington-Carranballac Road
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority. 

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 07:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for the State of Victoria

Bushfire smoke is impacting air quality in many areas across Victoria.

  • Extremely Poor air quality is currently being experienced in the North East forecast district.
  • Very Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Mallee, Northern Country, and West and South Gippsland forecast districts.
  • Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Central, South West and Wimmera.
  • Fair air quality is currently being experienced in North Central and East Gippsland forecast districts.
  • From Tuesday 13 January 2026 onwards, the forecast across the state is Poor air quality, except for Central district which is Fair.
  • Extreme heat and bushfire smoke are both harmful to health and the effects of heat exposure can have serious consequences for sensitive individuals.
  • Excessive smoke can aggravate existing heart and lung conditions and cause irritated eyes, coughing and wheezing. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice issued Sunday, 11 January 2026 at 8:00 pm.
Smoke can affect people's health. Take steps to reduce your exposure and protect the health of yourself and others.
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • You can self-assess the air quality near you using these tools. Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/smoke-and-your-health.
What you can do:
  • Listen to your local emergency radio station.
  • Check the air quality in your area here: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/check-air-and-water-quality.
  • Stay indoors away from smoke. If you must go outside when it is very smoky, consider wearing a mask (P2 or N95).
  • Close your windows and doors to keep smoke out of your home.
Keep the air inside your home as clean as possible. You can do this by:
  • Closing windows and doors and opening them when air quality improves, using your split system air conditioner or switching other types of air conditioners to recirculate if they have this function, not using evaporative coolers because they bring outdoor air inside.
  • Using an indoor air cleaner, if you have one, that has a high efficiency particle air (HEPA) filter that is the right size for the room.
  • If you think the air in your home is still uncomfortable, consider relocating if it is safe to do so. For example, go to an air-conditioned building like a library or shopping centre. 
  • You may also consider using a P2 or N95 mask but seek advice from your doctor if you have a pre-existing heart or lung condition.
  • People who are sensitive (people with a heart or lung condition, including asthma; people over the age of 65; infants and young children; pregnant women; and people with diabetes) to smoke should actively monitor symptoms and follow their health management plan recommended by their doctor.
  • If you are worried about your symptoms, see your doctor or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • If you or anyone in your care has trouble breathing, chest pain or discomfort, call Triple Zero (000) for an ambulance.
Impacts in your area:
  • Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.
  • Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the fires.
  • Environment Protection Authority is monitoring air quality across the state. 
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

The next update is expected by 13/01/2026 08:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - AIR QUALITY - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Statewide
Issue Date: Monday 12 January 2026, 07:49 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 13 January 2026, 08:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/40002/moreinfo

This Advice is being issued for the State of Victoria

Bushfire smoke is impacting air quality in many areas across Victoria. 

- Extremely Poor air quality is currently being experienced in the North East forecast district.
- Very Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Mallee, Northern Country, and West and South Gippsland forecast districts.
- Poor air quality is currently being experienced in Central, South West and Wimmera.
- Fair air quality is currently being experienced in North Central and East Gippsland forecast districts.
- From Tuesday 13 January 2026 onwards, the forecast across the state is Poor air quality, except for Central district which is Fair.
- Extreme heat and bushfire smoke are both harmful to health and the effects of heat exposure can have serious consequences for sensitive individuals.
- Excessive smoke can aggravate existing heart and lung conditions and cause irritated eyes, coughing and wheezing. 
- This Advice message replaces the Advice issued Sunday, 11 January 2026 at 8:00 pm.


<!--StartFragment-->Smoke can affect people's health. Take steps to reduce your exposure and protect the health of yourself and others.<!--EndFragment-->
